title: 105_s1923
content: The Act titled "Federal Facilities Clean Water Compliance Act of 1998" applies certain provisions to federal facilities. Section 313 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1323) is amended to redefine subsections and clarify the definition of reasonable service charges related to water pollution control programs. The Federal Government must comply with all requirements for controlling and reducing water pollution, including permits, reporting, injunctive relief, and sanctions imposed by courts. The United States waives immunity for water pollution control requirements, including injunctive relief, sanctions, enforcement orders, penalties, and service charges. The United States waives immunity for water pollution control requirements, including administrative orders, civil penalties, and injunctive relief enforcement in State or Federal courts. The United States waives immunity for water pollution control requirements, including administrative orders, civil penalties, and injunctive relief enforcement in State or Federal courts. Agents, employees, and officers of the United States can face criminal penalties for acts related to water pollution under Federal or State laws. No department, agency, or branch of the Federal Government is exempt from such penalties. The judicial branch of the Federal Government may face sanctions under administrative enforcement actions initiated by the Administrator, Secretary of the Army, or Secretary of the department where the Coast Guard operates. No department, agency, or branch of the Federal Government is exempt from these enforcement authorities. The Federal Government's judicial branch may be subject to administrative enforcement actions initiated by the Administrator, Secretary of the Army, or relevant department. Consent orders are required for voluntary resolutions, and departments must confer with the Administrator or Secretary before finalizing administrative orders. States are limited in using funds collected from the Federal Government. Government funds collected from the Federal Government for violations must be used by the State for environmental projects or enforcement costs, unless State law dictates otherwise. SEC. 3. DEFINITION OF PERSON. Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include departments, agencies, or instrumentalities of the United States in the definition of a person for oil and hazardous substance liability programs.
